answer_html: \(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} = \frac{1}{4}\)and so the sequence converges to one fourth.
answer_latex: $\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} = \frac{1}{4}$and so the sequence converges to one fourth.
hints_html:
Don’t let the square and cube roots fool you! This is still essentially a polynomial divided by a polynomial so factor out the largest power of n in both the numerator and the denominator.

What are the dominant terms when \(n\) is large?
hints_latex:
Don't let the square and cube roots fool you! This is still essentially
a polynomial divided by a polynomial so factor out the largest power of
\emph{n} in both the numerator and the denominator.
What are the dominant terms when $n$ is large?
hints_raw:
Don't let the square and cube roots fool you! This is still essentially a polynomial divided by a polynomial so factor out the largest power of ''n'' in both the numerator and the denominator.
What are the dominant terms when <math> n </math> is large?
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
Proceeding as in the hint, we have

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} &= \frac{n^3(1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3})}{\sqrt{n^6(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}} \\ &= \frac{n^3(1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3})} {n^3\sqrt{(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + 3n^3\sqrt[3]{(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}} \\ &= \frac{1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3}} {\sqrt{(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + 3\sqrt[3]{(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}}\end{aligned}\]

Taking the limit as n tends to infinity in the last equality above yields

\(\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} = \lim_{n \to \infty}\frac{1 + \tfrac{2}{n^3}} {\sqrt{(1+\tfrac{3}{n^6})} + 3\sqrt[3]{(1 + \tfrac{1}{27n^9})}} = \frac{1}{1 + 3} = \frac{1}{4}\)

and so the sequence converges to one fourth.
statement_html:
Sequences and Series: Short Answer Problems - Determine whether the following sequences and series converge (full marks for correct answer with justification; work must be shown for partial marks)

Does the sequence \(\left(\frac{n^3 + 2}{\sqrt{n^6+3} + \sqrt[3]{27n^9 + 1}} \right)_{n \geq 1}\) converge? If it does, calculate the limit.
